This PR adds support for `HorizontalLayout` in `layout` module. Below is a screenshot for reference.

![Screenshot (4)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54466356/127688192-8412b604-d6c7-4da9-87c4-dfae044a136e.png)

This it's related with  #428

Hi @Garyfallidis and @skoudoro. I didn't finish yet, but I'm sending the pull-request to get feedbacks or suggestions.

I've created a function inside of shaders/base.py (shader_apply_effects) in order to make the control of the opengl_state more  simple.

```python
id_observer = shader_apply_effects(
    showm, actorAdd,
    effect=window.gl_set_additive_blending)

###############################################################################
# It's also possible to pass a list of effects. The final opengl state it'll  be the composition of each 
# effect that each function has in the opengl state

id_observer =  shader_apply_effects(
    showm, actorNoDepthTest2,
    effects=[
        window.gl_reset_blend, window.gl_disable_blend,
        window.gl_disable_depth])
 ```

pr_title: Implements IPC tools to enhance network layout libs. Adds MDE-IPC
pr_body: Usually, network layout libs like pmde implements the computation inside of the python main thread. Therefore, due GIL, it is impossible to have a free interface at same time that the node positions are been computed. This PR implements an IPC to deal with that issue.

pr_title: implements a behavior that allows recording the evolution of the positions of any IPClayout algorithm
pr_body:
Example without recording
```python
from helios.layouts.mde import MDE

mde = MDE(edges, network, penalty_name='cubic',constraint_name='standardized')
mde.start(300, 200, 1, record_positions=False)
```
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6979335/126173934-6e5457b7-1d7e-4b8f-9598-8e2b81dfb5d7.mp4

Example with recording
```python
from helios.layouts.mde import MDE

mde = MDE(edges, network, penalty_name='cubic',constraint_name='standardized')
mde.start(300, 200, 1, record_positions=True)
```

pr_title: This PR creates an actor to draw labels using texture maps
pr_body:
- I've created  the actor and tests in different files just for help me to develop this PR. But latter I'll put everything inside of  actors.py and test_actors.py. 

To create pre-built texture atlas for FURY you just need to put the ttf files inside of `data/files` and run the following command
```bash
python -c 'from fury import text_tools;text_tools._create_fury_system_atlas_fonts()'
```


The example 
[docs/examples/viz_billboard_labels.py](https://github.com/fury-gl/fury/blob/c05b1c06e84be97a32abf84565359dd4dfda3c13/docs/examples/viz_billboard_labels.py)
shows almost all the behaviors available for this PR

Result with bitmap texture
![Screenshot_20210815_134435](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6979335/129485892-f8136c04-a86b-4a1a-8680-9053c7b4e1ad.png)

Result with SDF
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6979335/135487491-dd5b9445-b492-49b2-be9c-27128ffd969c.png)
